rsbNotes.title: Ps 113
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 113 God is both transcendent (vv. 4–6) and immanent (vv. 7–9); above creation but present with His people. Ps. 113 is the first of several psalms used to celebrate the great annual festivals of Passover, Weeks, Tabernacles, New Moon, and the Dedication of the temple. Ps. 113–118 were sung during the Passover, so it is likely that Jesus and His disciples sang them during their last evening together (Matt. 26:30; Mark 14:26). Ps. 113 (see v. 9) should be compared with the songs of Hannah (1 Sam. 2, especially vv. 5, 8) and Mary (Luke 1:46–55).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 113:1
rsbNotes.text: 113:1 O servants of the Lord. A priest leads the faithful in worship.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 113:3
rsbNotes.text: 113:3 From the rising of the sun to its setting. That is, from east to west, everywhere.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 113:4
rsbNotes.text: 113:4 high above all nations. In the ancient Near East each nation had its imagined national gods. Only the God of Israel could proclaim Himself the true God of all nations.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 113:5
rsbNotes.text: 113:5 Who is like. Yahweh is incomparable.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 113:6
rsbNotes.text:
113:6 who looks far down. Part of God’s greatness is His condescension, as at Bethlehem (Luke 2:4–7; Phil. 2:5–11).

on the heavens. Often the heavens are spoken of as the dwelling place of God, but strictly speaking, God’s infinite transcendence is such that even the heavens are unable to contain Him (1 Kin. 8:27).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 114
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 114 Jewish tradition assigned this psalm to the eighth day of Passover. In eight short verses, and with virtually unrivaled poetic subtlety, the psalmist describes the tremendous power of God’s visual self-revelation (theophany) at the time of Israel’s salvation from Egypt and entry into Canaan (Ex. 13:21).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 114:1
rsbNotes.text: 114:1 went out from Egypt. The Exodus was the most tremendous display of God’s redemptive power during the Old Testament period. It was constantly remembered and became a source of encouragement for later generations, including Christians who perceive themselves as “strangers and exiles” in search of their true “homeland” (Heb. 11:13, 14).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 114:2
rsbNotes.text: 114:2 his sanctuary. The people and their country were God’s sanctuary because God chose to be present with them. The tabernacle, and then the temple, were symbols of His presence.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 114:3
rsbNotes.text: 114:3 The sea looked. The Red Sea is personified (Ex. 14; 15), poetically describing the crossing of the sea as a conflict between it and the Lord.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 114:4
rsbNotes.text: 114:4 The mountains. The mountains were symbols of power, firmness, and endurance (Ps. 46). God’s appearance shakes them like frightened rams.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 114:5
rsbNotes.text: 114:5 What ails you. The psalmist questions the poetically personified sea and mountains making explicit what was implicit in the first two stanzas of the poem.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 114:7
rsbNotes.text: 114:7 Tremble. When God comes in judgment and with power, the inhabitants of the earth should fear because they will be objects of His judgment. Nothing can stand in His way.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 114:8
rsbNotes.text: 114:8 turns the rock into a pool. God’s provision at Kadesh (Num. 20:1–13) demonstrates His power and compassion.
